title: What are the steps I need to take if I am being sued by a debt collector?
question: I started a business after college but the business ended up failing. I did not incorporate and operated as a sole proprietorship and now all the debt that I incurred for the business is in default under my personal name. Debt collector have been getting more aggressive as time goes on and now I am getting sued by them. It seems like bankruptcy is a good option but I am unsure.
question_tags: Sole proprietorship,Bankruptcy,Chapter 7 bankruptcy,Chapter 7 bankruptcy means test,Chapter 13 bankruptcy,Debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Chapter 13 bankruptcy reorganization plan
answers:
Schedule a free consultation with a reputable and experienced bankruptcy attorney and learn more about your options.
Best of luck.

A failed business and the subsequent debt burden and exposure to creditor claims is one of many reasons that individuals like yourself seek out the protection and relief of federal bankruptcy law.

Depending on a more complete and comprehensive analysis of your income and expenses, debt characteristics, asset analysis and bankruptcy’s means test, you may be a good candidate for a chapter 7 bankruptcy or a chapter 13 bankruptcy, in the alternative. Most bankruptcy attorney’s will offer a free consultation, ideally providing you with valuable information to help you determine your options and possible next steps to address the financial hurdles, which may include seeking a fresh start via a Bankruptcy order and discharge of your debts.

Best of luck
Depending on how much debt you have, bankruptcy is not only a good option - it may be the only option since the judgment(s) can likely be removed during the BK.
Most bankruptcy attorneys offer free initial consults. Use the find a Lawyer tab on AVVO to find one or two in your area. From your question, it appears that bankruptcy could be a viable option.

It would be a very good idea to have the lawsuit reviewed by a local San Diego Attorney so you can discuss options. Dealing with a failed business can be daunting and debt collections can be nasty.

Contact a local San Diego Bankruptcy attorney asap because the time to respond to the lawsuit may very well be running.
